p: Pseudomonas aeruginosa was also detected by mNGS in BALF. Carbapenem was applied at local hospital but without response. It could be deduced that the Pseudomonas aeruginosa of the patient responded less sensitive to carbapenem. There was another possibility that Pseudomonas aeruginosa was hospital-acquired infections in ICU of our hospital. Before the detection of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the therapy of linezolid, piperacillin/tazobactam and TMP-SMX greatly relieved the patient's symptoms. Actually, linezolid and piperacillin/tazobactam also had clinical efficiency with Pseudomonas aeruginosa ( 31). Therefore, the former treatment was not changed and then patient completely recovered. Pseudomonas aeruginosa in this case may be more sensitive to piperacillin/tazobactam, or a combination of these drugs.
